contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox VG |title = Under Ash |image = |developer = |publisher = [[Dar al-Fikr]] |designer = |engine = |released = 2001 |genre = [[Action Game]], [[First Person Shooter|FPS]] |modes = [[Single player]] |ratings = |platforms = [[Personal computer|PC]] }} '''''Under Ash''''' (Arabic name: "''Taht-al-ramad''", '''تحت الرماد''') is a [[first-person shooter]] sometimes explained to be a response to how [[Arab]]s are pictured in [[video game]]s in general and ''[[America's Army]]'' in particular. Like ''America's Army'', it is considered to be video game [[propaganda]]; however, it differs from ''America's Army'' in that it is not available free. The player takes the role of Ahmed, a [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] opposed to [[Israel]]i occupation ([[Zionism|"Zionists"]]). Through the course of the game, Ahmed progresses from throwing rocks at Israeli soldiers to destroying Israeli military positions. The game has been criticized for being too hard, and is designed so that it's easy to be killed.<ref name=BBC>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/2019677.stm BBC: Syria launches Arab war game]</ref> If you shoot a civilian, the game ends automatically. In the end it isn't even possible to achieve a victory.<ref name=BBC/> The game was published by [[Dar al-Fikr]], a [[Syria]]n publishing company, and the first pressing of ten thousand copies sold out in a week. {{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} Its relevance to the fighting in the [[Middle East]] makes it a [[controversial video game]]. The developers say it was made with a similar motive to ''[[Delta Force (video game)|Delta Force]]'' and ''[[America's Army]]''.
